reviewText:
It's not only one of the best Transformers games out there, it's also one hell of an action game, with a unique theme, varied gameplay and lots of cool mechanics not present in other third person shooters. Though the story and execution are not as epic as the sequel - Fall of Cybertron - the overall gameplay is still thoroughly enjoyable and well paced. WfC also offers a bit better vehicle sections than FoC, and way better and more challenging boss fights. Not to mention, being able to select one of three characters available for a specific chapter is definitely a plus.

People familiar with the Transformers will immediatelly appreciate the amazing animations and the artstyle faithful to Generation One, but the overall graphics are impressive on their own. One drawback I can think of in that regard is that it can be too dark/brown at times, with enemies being hard to distinguish from the rest of the environment. As for the audio, let's just say it's almost flawless, featuring some great music tracks, quite powerful sound effects, and an amazing voiceover, with numerous actors reprising their roles as familiar robots from the original show.

Still, even though the PC port is very much playable, it's quite lacking in many respects. From unrebindable controls, 30fps lock, minimal graphics options, to a complete lack of DLC, and multiplayer being full of cheaters. That aside though, it's still an awesome shooter, worth playing despite these drawbacks for the story campaign alone.

reviewText:
Transformers: War for Cybertron is a 3rd Person Action Shooter. The Cybertronian Civil War takes a turn when Megatron and his Decepticons get hold of an ancient power source, just as a new Autobot leader emerges to face him.

Pros: The story, although linear, is solid with great voice acting and writing, as you walk the grounds of Cybertron facilities, prisons and cities in a 10-chapter campaign that has you battling in squads of iconic characters from the series. Each chapter will have you choose from three characters with different class, weapons and vehicle form, a selection that varies with each chapter. Transforming is an essential part of combat, as robot form allows you to jump, do special moves and carry up to two weapons, while vehicle mode allows faster movement and alternative weapon. Graphics are pretty good, textures being higher resolution in-game than in cut scenes, while sound effects feel genuine to Transformers.

Cons: Besides being able to transform, combat is nothing special, as there is no cover system beyond moving your character behind an obstacle, and weapons go from generic machine gun to generic shotgun, generic missile launcher, generic sniper, and anything in between. You might think melee combat would be an alternative, but in fact it feels worst as each melee strike takes a few seconds to complete, meaning you'll avoid using it at all in tougher fights unless the enemy AI happens to come within range. The characters, enemies, obstacles and backgrounds all have the same aesthetic and look, making it hard to know what's what in the heat of a firefight. As for the campaign length, well, let's just say they could've been longer seeing the only replay value lies with what's left of the multiplayer community.

Verdict: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† - Next on your list!

This isn't the Arkham Asylum of Transformers, but it's no doubt the best we'll get. Hasbro has certified it as an official canon prequel to the Transformers, so it's pretty awesome for a fan to see how Starscream came to join the Decepticon, how Optimus became a Prime, and what caused Cybertron to require evacuation. While non-fans may find this game to be a plain 3rd Person Shooter, I still strongly recommend it!

reviewText:
Transformers: War for Cybertron is a non-stop TPS action from start to finish.
The game tells the story of the civil war between the Autobots and Decepticions, which will eventually lead to the Autobot exile in the Fall of Cybertron sequel.
The campaign is split into 2 segments: 5 Decepticion missions and 5 Autobot missions.
Between each stage you have the option to choose 1 of the 3 character classes: Soldier, Scientist and Scout, each with its' strengths and weaknesses.
The story features quite a lot of the iconic robots from the Transformers universe: Megatron, Optimus Prime, Bumblebee, Starscream, Omega Supreme, Trypticon.... just to name a few, but the line-up is quite large.

The game is well optimized, it runs smooth on max settings, however the FPS is limited to 30, which might turn some people off.

Overall War for Cybertron is a great TPS action game, which is highly recommended if you like Transformers or just great TPS games in general!

PROS:
- Good looking visuals.
- Solid, responsive controls.
- Good atmosphere.
- Non-stop action.
- Decent story.
- Solid PC port: looks good and runs well, though the FPS is capped at 30.

CONS:
- 30 FPS limit.

High Moon Studios developed a game with a high degree for attention to detail, from fluid tranformations (that never get old) to moving to making the planet feel alive. When there was a full scale battle the player can feel like there are actual bots fighting on the allied side and the opposing side. One thing I didn't like was the scaling of the bot models. There should be a very noticeable size difference between someone like Megatron and Starscream.

The game mechanics are nice, but flawed. Shooting and switching weapons is very snappy and responsive on the gamepad and mouse. The melee system leaves too much to be desired. The animation can vary from being too delayed to being too prolonged. The ammo system can be very frustrating. Ammo is more scarce then I would have liked, but the reloading is fluid. I would have done away with the whole system completely. A cooldown method would have been more effective and immersive. Or maybe nothing of the sort at all. I also would have liked if the guns were for sci-fi like. The various weapons were too human-esque for my liking. A Bay approach to the weapons would have been worlds better.

Overall, I enjoyed this game immensely and I am eager to play the second.

Transformers War For Cybertron is your basic third-person shooter but with autobots and decepticons duking it out on a cyber-world. It's got a variety of missions and plenty of characters to choose from in this double-sided campaign.

There's so much to say about this game and how much it surprised me when I first played it. It's smooth and polished gameplay made it very to get into from the start. You wouldn't think that a game set in a metallic world could become so immersive but High Moon Studios did an amazing job of making you feel as if you are on the planet.

The game is broken up into different levels so it's not an open world game, however, each level are a pretty decent size and there are multiple ways to go about them. Each level allows you to select between 3 characters and each has their own unique special ability.Â  They look different and their transformations and speed are different.

There's alot going on in the game, whether you are looking at what's going on right in front of you or maybe some space battle happening in the distance, the world is full of things for you to look at and it does really look like a war is going on. The world is made of moving parts, so it's not like the characters are the only things that transform and have moving parts, moreover the planet is alivea and waiting for you to rescue it.

Pros  Exceptional voice acting
Diverse choice of characters from Autobots and Decepticons
Smooth driving mechanics, shooting feels great
Doesn't get boring - even though all you do is run around and shoot stuff
DecentÂ  story
Controller support
Cons  Few graphics options
Everything looks like metal so it can be confusing
No reason to play it after you've beaten it
Final Thoughts:
A great Transformers game, hits all the right strings for true fans of the franchise. Easy to pick up and master and the game's not short. A great start to the Cybertron game series. Also, don't buy this for the multiplayer, buy it for the single player experience.

reviewText:
Note: This review is for the solo campaign mode only.

Note 2: The game is locked at 30 fps by default. You can download an uncapper (see the game's PCGamingWiki entry) that will allow you to unlock the frame rate with no negative gameplay effects. With the uncapper, I was able to get 60 fps most of the time on my i5-3470/GTX 970 system. There were still sporadic moments where it would dip back into the 30s for a few seconds, though this happened even on minimum settings, so I have to assume this was just the result of some flaw that the uncapper couldn't fix rather than my hardware. These were rare enough to not negatively affect my enjoyment of the game.

Gameplay review: This game is actually the first Transformers story I've ever experienced in any medium and I enjoyed the story more than I was expecting. I think a lot of that has to do with the great voice acting.

The gameplay is generic, but satisfying, third-person shooting that succeeds because of the sheer amount of spectacle. It's quite linear but the strong pacing kept me interested regardless.

The game is split into two five-mission campaigns: the initial Decepticon campaign, which features Megatron doing generic evil genius stuff, and the Autobot campaign, in which Optimus attempts to foil Megatron's plans.

While the gameplay between the two campaigns is mostly the same, the Autobot campaign is much harder than the Decepticon campaign. I played on hard, and despite the campaigns having the same number of levels, it took me 4 hours to beat the Decepticon campaign and 10 hours to beat the Autobot campaign. Even on hard, the Decepticon campaign is staggeringly easy, but the degree of difficulty ramps up massively in the second mission of the Autobot campaign and remains that way until the end of the game.

The main reason for this is a difference in the design of the combat spaces between the two campaigns: Levels in the Decepticon campaign tend to feature lots of linear corridors and small rooms with plenty of cover, which means you can stand behind cover and blast enemies to your heart's content. Rooms also usually only feature 3-5 enemies at most. However, in the Autobot campaign, you're frequently placed into large arena-like spaces with very limited cover, limited health pick-ups, and overwhelming numbers of spongey enemies. Dodging and pinpoint accuracy become essential for survival. The degree with which the difficulty increases almost made me give up, but I stuck it out until the end I guess through stubbornness?

If you don't like being frustrated by your games, you might want to play this one on medium. If you like a real challenge, play on hard, and you'll find what you're looking for once you get through the first five easy levels.

reviewText:
I liked Transformers: War for Cybertron even though I should've hated it. It's a straightforward third-person shooter that doesn't do anything particularly well. The shooting is average, the movement is sub-par, the environments are entirely linear corridor-style affairs - even when flying in space. But the Transformers save the day with their ridiculous over-the-top dialogue and voice acting. It also helps that enemies and environments are suitably epic.

So what's the game about? Transforming cars/planes fighting each other on their mechanical home planet. That's awesome if you're a Transformers fan. It's also awesome if you've never seen a Transformers movie / cartoon / comic ever. Don't bother with the details; they don't matter. Purple is fighting Red - that's all you need to know.

Two short campaigns - one each for the Decepticons and Autobots - fill in the singleplayer offering. But these are also playable in co-op with up to 2 friends. In singleplayer you get two AI buddies who tend to be in your way more than they actually help out. The game is substantially better - and easier - in co-op. Then there's a horde mode and regular old multiplayer. No one really seems to be playing those anymore, so let's just stick with the campaign / co-op.

So far it doesn't sound all that bad, so why should I have hated it? That's where the horrendous PC port rears its ugly head. Transformers: War for Cybertron fails on nearly every level a port can fail at. Every horror story you've heard about awful PC ports is present in this one. A ridiculous 30FPS limit. Non-rebindable keys with awful default settings. Terrible texturework throughout. Zero graphics options. Noticeable mouse acceleration, albeit far from the worst I've seen. Random crashing. Alt-tab crashing. You name it, this game's got it.

I managed to unlock the FPS using a third party tool. Likewise added anti-aliasing using nvidiaInspector, because simply forcing through drivers doesn't work. After that it was mostly playable apart from occasional crashes. The aforementioned should've ruined the experience for me, but the insane setpieces and awesome Transformers still made it work.

If there was ever a game that deserved to be called greater than the sum of its parts, this is it.

Conclusion / TLDR
Transformers: War for Cybertron is fun to play, particularly with friends. But it's a deeply flawed experience, mainly due to constant severe technical difficulties. It's worth playing, but only just - and probably better on consoles.

reviewText:
Transformers War For Cybertron is a love letter to the 1980's era Transformers and if you're a fan of the series young or old you'll probably find something to love about Transformers Fall of Cybertron, and have enough fond feelings to overlook some of the problems this PC port has.

The game play is third person action shooter that has you running gunning and transforming. Most sections are designed for robot combat and you'll strafe around shooting at the opposition but a few areas are designed for mobility in mind where transforming into your vehicle mode is required. These segments are well done and the transition from robot to vehicle feels as good as you'd expect it should. The shooting segments can get repetitive and with out a cover option you'll find yourself mostly strafing back and forth to avoid fire which feels a bit clunky. You'll often find your friendly AI companions getting in the way and they 're really only there for you to have a choice of one of three characters to choose from at the beginning of each mission and for bantering back and forth. There was never a time I felt like they did any thing to help me, and a few times where they got in the way.

Multilayer is a lot more fun then I expected. You level up your class, customize skills based off your play style. Its actually pretty diverse and fun.

The game can be visually cluttered at times, as a living robotic planet with lots of moving parts is important to the setting but can get sort of messy on screen when laser battles are breaking out and you're shifting in between robot and vehicle forms but it's a minor complaint. If you play with a controller it's a bit annoying that it's only partially supported, so get used to memorizing buttons as every in-game prompt you see will be keyboard & mouse specific. I never ran into any major problems because of this but it was annoying.

All and all a fun time to be had, especially if you're a fan of the series. And it's got a Stan Bush song... What else can I say?

reviewText:
Initially, I bought the game because I was a huge Transformers fan and it looked pretty awesome from the trailer.

But, after buying this game (on disk initially, then on Steam a few months ago during a sale) I can truly say that this game has merits not related to anything Transformers.

For example, all of the gameplay you can do in War for Cybertron can be multiplayer. Now, I'm a fan of all things multiplayer, because it keeps making the gameplay different. As long as you play with other people, no one match will be the same. This game requires a high level of adaptivity and improvisation, and I can honestly say it's one of the harder games I've played.

Let's break down the other aspects of this game, shall we?

First off, the campaign.
While playing through the campaign, I found myself stopping to admire the levels. Everything in this game is beautiful, intricate, and promises grandeur. Albeit at some points it's just an incredible backdrop to okay levels, but let me just put it this way: If this game was open world, I wouldn't play anything else.
The boss fights were interesting, and get substantially more difficult when you put the game on hard. The characters and abilities that you get to use are incredibly effective, if you take the time to learn how to use them.

Secondly, Escalation mode.
Escalation is a zombies-like gamemode in which you and at least one other person are trapped in one of two maps, one for Autobots and the other for Decepticons. Waves of increasingly difficult enemies are thrown at you and it becomes harder and harder to survive. You earn points from killing enemies, which you can spend for guns, ammo, health, grenades, anything you need to kill more efficiently. The sigils in the game can be found in the map, instead of any overlay or GUI shop. You can also spend points to open doors, which unlocks further areas in the map that you play as well as unlocking more guns, ammo, etc.
All in all, Escalation is pretty fun and challenging, but it does get a bit repeditive.

Regular Multiplayer
The multiplayer in War for Cybertron will be different than that from other popular shooter games, as there are only about six maps to choose from, and four classes. The abilities and weapons are wildly customizable, and real skill and strategy are required in order to be any good. But, the fun thing about the multiplayer is that you can suck and still have fun. The multiplayer never gets boring, but it can be a little frustrating at times. Each class has a definitive strategy to it, and you will have your favorite.
Take, for example, the scout:
If you have a good aim, nice reflexes and know the basics of cloak-and-dagger combat, this is the class for you.
The soldier, however, is different in every way. Over twice the health, more powerful and easier to use guns, as well as a devestating melee attack and a tank cannon make this character dangerous if used correctly. However, the cliche of the dumb brute also takes hold here, as the soldier is slow and ineffective against fleeing targets. In a fight, however, or gunning down weakened enemies the soldier is a complete powerhouse.

There's honestly nothing I can say that does this game justice. It's not perfect, yes, but no game is. It has its' quirks, and you're just going to have to get used to them. But, as someone who plays this game almost religiously, I must say that there is more to this game than meets the eye.

reviewText:
War for Cybertron is to Transformers games, what Arkham Asylum is to Batman games. While Fall of Cybertron is a much better game in terms of gameplay, graphics, and audio, War for Cybertron is a fun game which will be an absolute thrill to Transformers fans, both young and old.

Pros:
+Voice acting is excellent. Although Frank Weller does not perform the voice of Megatron, the actor in this game does an excellent job of portraying the strongest Decepticon.
+Lighting and color pallete are well suited to the games themes.
+Gameplay is very smooth. You feel as though you actually are a transformer.
+Multiplayer is excellently done (You can customize your own transformer!)
+Story is well written. Both campaigns feel like an episode of transformers.
+Subtle references to the Original series are made throughout the game.

Cons:
-30 Fps Cap. Not a huge deal, but for some this may be an annoyance.
-MULTIPLAYER IS DEAD.
-Some visual glitches can occur from time to time.
-Soundwave transforms into a car.
-Story can be somewhat short, depending on your skill level and the difficulty at which you play.
-Graphics settings are a bit lacking. There are very few options.

Overall, Transformers War for Cybertron is a game that any Transformers fan is sure to fall in love with.
8/10

More than meets the eye? I don't know, but what I know is that this is a good Transformers game. I mean if you can play as Optimus and Megatron it can't be a bad game, right? And the voice-acting is still done by Peter Cullen who has always been the voice actor for Optimus Prime (or at least in the '80s TV show and the film adaptations).

You have two separate campaigns (one for the Autobots and one for the Decepticons), each with 5 levels and 3 playable characters. The reason for the 3 characters are the coop approach High Moon studios followed for this game (I understand they skipped this when it comes to the sequel). It's OK to play it alone as the AI can focus on the other two robots and they are actively engaged in combat. Obviously, a human player is much better but the upside is that you do not need to revive them as they basically never perish.

10 hours is not much for the two campaign walkthroughs but the levels are relatively long and varied. Also, there are some pretty neat boss battles where you encounter huge transformers. Ever wanted to defeat Omega Supreme? Or that annoying Tripticon? Now you have the chance for that!

Gameplay is pretty straightforward. Sometimes you activate switches to make further progress, other times you just shoot everything that moves. Combat is pretty fluid - your transformers have melee and two abilities that you can charge whilst fighting with the enemy. You can also transform - ground vehicles and planes are options on both sides.

The game is hard. I mean HARD. But there's a learning curve there so you should keep trying. I guess this is easier if you have friends - still, I enjoyed the single player game alone with the AI controlled assistance.

There are many references to the Transformers universe which only proves that High Moon Studios was very committed in the making of this game. Too bad the multiplayer is not played any more so I can only comment on the single player campaign.

I recommend this game but for a relatively short campaign 20 EUR is a bit too much. Once it is discounted it should definitely land in your baskets.

Transformersâ„¢: War for Cybertonâ„¢ is easily the best Transformers Trademark gave I've ever played.

Okay, enough with the trademarks. Honestly though, the game has a solid story where you get to see both sides of the war for Cybertron. And seeing the ware take place from both the Decepticons and the Autobots, it's actually easy to align your views with either faction when in the midst of battle. With the Decepticons; you have the minions bickering and often making off comments about Megatron, only to immediately apologize and say they meant someone else, and with the Autobots, you have the stoic leadership of Optimus leading the charge with the quirky charm of side characters like Bumblebee.

If you don't know the story, basically, there's a civil war going on and Megatron aims to shift the victory towards the Decepticons by taking over a station ran by Starscream and aims to gain control of dark energon. The Autobot story is set, chronologically, after the Decepticon story is over, and it's their re-organization and retaliation for what the Decepticons have done.

What I love about Transformers, at least in this game, is there's no emotional attachment to any of the characters. It's a straight up action/3rd person shooter where the goal is to progress deep into enemy territory and win the battle. That's the core concept of it. Both stories are interesting, but ultimately, I think I liked the Decepticon story in this game more, just because of how complex Megatron can be. He's brutal but proud and wants to further the advancement of bots through evil means.

The other great thing about this game might be the options when it comes to selecting your character. On each mission, you're able to choose between three characters, some repeating themselves, but the character choices were usually different. The graphics do look a bit dated, but it probably doesn't help that the atmosphere for most of the game is dark or indoors where everything is metal or concrete with various lighting setups. Basically, the environments weren't that amazing to look at. But the scope of the outer space scenes was remarkable. Sound design is key here, it's pretty great. I liked the soundtrack too.

Not a perfect game, a bit repetitive with the fighting and the story never really arced, it just kind of flowed in a straight line but I still enjoyed it.

TL;DR (Sort of)

Pros :

- PETER CULLEN
- Escalation is really damn fun if you have people to play with

- No host migrations

Now I can see you clicking off because there's more cons than pros but the thing is, these cons aren't anything too bad. I mean most of them can be fixed by either looking up configs or using third party tools. This game is honestly one of the very best MP games of all time

The graphics are very sharp, and stand up years later -- but you'd better get used to samey machanical corridors, with nice set pieces only scattered here and there.

The voicework is excellent and involves many actors who've worked on the cartoon -- but the music is generic action movie droning, at best.

The gameplay is tight, and it's nice to have access to a vehicle in a shooter like this at all times with your alt form -- but aside from that (and perhaps the ability to lug around turrets with your giant robot arms) there is nothing fresh here, even for 2010.

TL;DR - Yes, the shooting mechanics themselves are somewhat clunky, but it's still an effing TRANSFORMERS THIRD-PERSON SHOOTER, and it works!

Of all the things in the gaming world, I would have never expected the successful fusion of the Transformers brand and a third-person shooter, yet, here we are. Somebody more articulate than I once said that â€œWar for Cybertronâ€ and its sequels were essentially the equivalent of the Batman Arkham games; both reinvent these franchises in the gaming world with gameplay systems that prove surprisingly effective in supporting the setting and characters. Granted, my (albeit limited) knowledge of Transformers doesnâ€™t really include mowing down waves upon waves of nameless Cybertronians using one of three varieties of machine gun, but the core aesthetic of teamed-up, tough-talking transforming space robots is still present and strong.

The shooting mechanics themselves are thankfully varied; in addition to the existence of a sizable arsenal, the ability to transform into a vehicle and grant yourself a completely different loadout (with its own reserve of ammo) ensures that you never really stop â€œgoingâ€ through a level. A lot of the luster in the weaponry lies in the flashy pyrotechnics they produce; it may be an Unreal Engine 3 game, but it still is quite a looker by todayâ€™s standards. The gameâ€™s excellent pacing exists also in thanks to variability in level design; sure, the concept of the â€œaction setpieceâ€ is an often lambasted one, but the frequency at which War for Cybertron throws different ones at you is something to be admired, at least.

That said, War for Cybertron is by no means a â€œGears of Warâ€-quality TPS; for all of the aftermentioned flashiness and particle effects, there lacks a certain gravity in how weapons effect enemies.  In other words: â€œbulletspongeâ€ enemies, and a lot of them at that, especially in the late game. Also, the lack of a â€œhold to aim/zoomâ€ toggle is annoying, but not as sizable a problem as the gameâ€™s biggest sin of incomplete controller support. Yes, the game is technically playable using a 360 controller, but good luck finding documentation of any kind on what actions the buttons are assigned to. Iâ€™ve also heard that certain vehicle sections are not mapped correctly, making the prospect of successfully using a controller unlikely, to say the least.

Final words: In the end however, I think Transformers: War for Cybertron is definitely worth a play, because when all is said and done, itâ€™s still a totally competent shooter. By itself, thatâ€™s not much of a feat, but when attached to the Transformers brand, of all properties, it totally freaking is.

reviewText:
Bow down to the best game in the Transformers franchise.

This game is so good, it's almost on point. Transformers: War for Cybertron is a FPS based on events that take place before Generation 1/Prime with a few strings pulled from here and there for creative flexibility. From the unique cybertronian designs to a beautifully set up storyline, High Moon did a fantastic job here. Might I say the character personalities are amazing, the portrayal of the individual Seekers' personality really made me happy and are just how I always interpreted them. Watching the transformation of Orion Pax to Optimus Prime. I really like this game and I love the campaign.

Now for the disappointing half, I played this back on Xbox 360 when it first released. I got the DLC, some of which were characters like Shockwave and the map packs. Had a good time in multiplayer leveling up my character, no problem. Now I find out WFC is on PC. Fun, right? Wrong. Not only is this game missing patches but NONE of the DLC presented on he consoles are provided here. That's about 7ish characters we're missing out on for multiplayer?

Speaking of multiplayer, don't try it. Firstly, it's just about always dead now. Secondly, the games are infested with cheaters. Infinite armor, FPS unlocker, rapid fire, etc. Does High Moon do anything about this? No. Will High Moon do anything about this? No. Do not set foot in a public game unless you want to lose because you're sure as hell not winning.

High Moon Studios, what the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥?

Not only that but this game was abandonded as soon as it was dropped on Steam for their sequel game, Fall of Cybertron, WHICH IS JUST AS BROKEN AND CHAOTIC AS THIS GAME. High Moon Studios took priority over their console games rather than PC. Why wasn't there any DLC released for this game? I would have happily forked out for it but instead they left us in the dust just so they could rush on their next game and abandon it as well.

I love High Moon Studios for this game, it is one of my all time favorites but the fact that there was no love or time taken to fix up and maintain the game on this platform severely disappoints me. If there was a in-between rating for games I would definately give it to this game. The only instance where I would recommend this game would only be for the campaign and escalation. Multiplayer has been ruined by a selfish community.

I can only recommend the full experience of WFC on Xbox or PS3.

reviewText:
This review is based on about the hour or so of gameplay I played during a $5 sale before returning the product. As such I am limited to what I experienced. Please keep this in mind!

War for Cybertron was a game that I heard a lot of good things about. With it being Transformers (a series that I enjoyed quite a bit in my childhood, although not quite on the same level as my brother) I was excited to give it a try. What I got was less than desirable. While I initially was reluctant to review a product that I had such little time with, I felt it was important to share my feelings about the game to give others a better sense of what they should expect / recieve.

The gameplay in this game is rather interesting. The fact that you can transform SEEMS like it would offer quite a bit of variation on combat. That's not quite true. Transforming merely seemed like another gun and a slightly altered means of transportation with flying, which is actually useful, and driving, which switches between sluggish or super sonic speed depending on your actions. This just feels clumsy and really serves more as a gimmick.

Jumping is odd. You have a double jump, but most obstacles feel like you need to use both anyway. Not solid, but I can't say it was terrible.

Camera controls. Ugh, I'm not a fan of them. Having an over the shoulder perspective is usually a hit or miss due to the fact that they often pick a side to stick with. This is USUALLY a bad design decision unless levels are built around that. This is a game that does that and isn't built for it. (At least as far as I could find control wise, correct me if I'm wrong.) Imagine hiding behind cover with a camera stuck on your right shoulder and an enemy attacking you. Due to the fact that he resides on the left side of the screen you are unable to attack him without coming out of cover.

Which leads to my next complaint. Cover is pretty much nonexistent. Sure you can stand behind things, but this feels incredibly inadequate and often leads to the damage you take feeling cheap. With a small health bar and only medkits to replenish health, it seems odd that avoiding damage is so tricky. (While I might have been bad at this game and thus affecting my view on this, I will say that I don't always suck.)

Ammo feels lacking. With most enemies taking at least half a magazine of bullets to finish off unless using a weapon with more sparse ammo (and thus being more deadly.) This means that the rigid car mode is something you'll find yourself stuck using to alleviate this problem.

Making an account for Co-op and online play is actually incredibly easy and gets major applause for it. All it asks is for a name and your pretty much good to go. No hassle and I was done in ten seconds flat. (Although adding a friend seems to be a mutual process.)

However the actual Co-op feels slapped on. Ammo and health had the biggest impact on this situation. The levels are designed to give enough for one player. When you add another robot providing support but using the same resources you start having someone (or even multiple) people in the party having to stay behind because they are out of something crucial. This could have easily been fixed by having the health and ammo work for both players, or just dropping duplicates of them.

Not only that but you'll find that if your partner runs just a little bit ahead, most doors end up closing on the other(s) before they can make it through. Their solution is to simply toss the player left behind into the next room. This is very disorienting and really isn't a good solution. Still it does get the job done.

The enviroment is definitely done well and really feels robotic" and futuristic. The problem I have with it though is that enemies are too easily hidden and indistinguishable from the background. This might have just been a problem for me.

The story is something I truly can't speak on. As I said at the start of this

reviewText:
Imagine that a cable science-fiction channel had an unexpected gap to fill in its programming and for contractual reasons with its advertisers the content had to be something new rather than a re-run. They tell their youngest unpaid interns about this at 5 o'clock as they're packing up to leave, saying it had better be ready to air by the next morning. Already exhausted from a mid-week birthday party that lasted well into the previous night, and having never done anything like this before, the interns must write, direct, act, and produce their own made-for-TV-movie in just a few hours.

That's exactly how Transformers: War for Cybertron must've been created.

The graphics and gameplay are just Unreal Tournament skinned with a few tweaks. Inaccurate, unpowerful weapons. Dull, blurry textures. Locked in third-person mode. Extremely slow movement speed even when things are supposed to be rushed. Collecting glowing shards from defeated enemies that do absolutely nothing. All the changes make things worse, and UT did not have a strong single player campaign to begin with.

The dialogue and voice acting are so bad as to be laughable if only the game didn't take itself so seriously. The story and some of its moments just shatter any suspension of disbelief. This is a problem with Transformers in general (why in the world would a group of alien machines transform into exact replicas of vehicles meant to transport humans when they've never seen any before (this is a prequel after all)? Or for that matter, why do they even have two arms, two legs, and faces? Those things are utterly irrelevant to a machine's existence) but this game exacerbates them. Oh there's a hard terminal to hack? The solution is to reduce the power being sent to it. Because a computer's incoming power affects its security. Idiotic doesn't even begin to describe it.

The one saving grace is the boss fights. Some of them are a fun diversion for a few moments. And they're consistently the only parts of the game that can't be ignored and just sprinted through. But they are the vast minority of where your time will be spent during a play through.

I bought this game to play co-op, but it's honestly one of the only games where I can't imagine co-op making it better. Maybe you'd be able to make fun of it with your partner in real time. What a silver lining that would be.

A great idea, and stunningly well designed, thought out game. The graphics are fantastic, the sound and voice acting a actually pretty surprisingly good... all around, it's a great game.
But...
The game is so agonizingly linear that it tends to ruin the rest of it. There are many, many places that are stunningly beautiful and complex, which could have made wonderful places to creep through and explore, but end up simply being a hallway with cutscenes and gunfights. Sections of the game that would have been perfectly set up to allow for multiple paths and player creativity are left with un-passable, knee-high walls to keep you on a single platform until the story decides to let you move on.
The vaunted ability to unlock more transformer chassis (in truth, there are only two, and it is the only way in the game to get a female transformer) and build your own character is woefully basic; effectively a choice of an existing character with a PARTIALLY different paint job built from a VERY limited color pallete selection. The custom characters are also ONLY available if you play multiplayer against other people, which is also the only way to level up and unlock new equipment and abilities (of which there tend to be may 2 at best for any given character type).

despite actually liking the game, it is so basic and bland that I couldn't stomach putting in the effort to finish it. I'll use the hard drive space for a game that doesnt drag me along by the wrist.

From a purely game mechanic perspective, this really isn't anything special; it's arguably sub-par. Unlike Binary Domain or Spec Ops, the title doesn't hold a compelling storyline that excuses the mediocre game mechanics. Hell, those titles at least had some differences in game mechanics that distanced them from typical titles of their respective genres. WFC gives you the ability to transform into vehicles, which really doesn't amount to anything more than a quicker way to traverse the landscape and a third in-game weapon. They really missed an opportunity here; it was somewhat explored in a few segments where you could drive through the landscape as it was engulfed in war, but otherwise it's really the biggest let-down of the game.

So why am I recommending this; am I a Transformers fan? Nah, I've never watched it and have stayed away from the recent movies. I came into this a Transformers virgin (har har har). I guess this TRANSFORMED me into a, you know, non-virgin or something (HAHAHAHAHAHAH)

I'm recommending this for the same reason I recommended Spec Ops and Binary Domain: interesting storyline. The story on this number is nowhere near the levels that BD and SO touched upon, but just because a plotline isn't ''deep'' doesn't mean it isn't interesting. WFC feels episodic; each chapter is introduced with a ''last time on Dragon Ball Z'' type of summary, and it all feels like a season of the show, like you're watching a cartoon and want to tune in to the next episode. Having no prior knowledge of the series, I feel that it does a good job of introducing newbies to the franchise and doesn't overwhelm you with the franchise's giant mythos. They also did this cool thing whereby you first play as the evil side before switching to the good in the aftermath of evil's victory. It's a really nice touch. The plotline is still simplistic, but the feel I got from it gave me a cozy saturday morning vibe that I thoroughly enjoyed. I didn't play it so much for the game mechanics, but to see how the Decepticons would strike back, or how the autobots would regroup.

Perhaps I'm a sucker for storylines because I feel like I should stop recommending titles just on that alone. But just as before I'll use the same logic: nothing is inherently flawed with the game mechanics, and the plot is what keeps you reeled in. The game is somewhat easy; I played on hard mode in co-op (two players, there's an option for three) and it was still a breeze, save for a few battles here and there. There's a multiplayer mode, but everyime I boot up the title and go online to host a game for me and the broski the in-game menu tells me that there are around 40 players online, so it's dead.

This game recommendation hinges on you enjoying a simplistic plotline that plays out like a saturday morning cartoon, or perhaps if you're into the series. Cause it does the series justice (according to a different review, at least) and when it comes to cash cow franchises you really can't expect a decent video game, but here it is. If I were to place a numerical score on this, I'd saaaayyy....

The war between the Autobots and the Decepticons is everpresent, having raged on for millions of years. As I traveled across the Cybertronian landscape, I was constantly struck by the scope of the devastation. Combined with the visceral and relentless combat, this really lends the game an ominous feel. You get the impression that there isn't much left to fight over, and that whatever victory either side might achieve will be phyrric at best.\n\nThe characters and narrative in this game are extremely strong, though the combat gets a bit repetative. There isn't much to the gameplay besides very basic third-person shooter elements, and the ability to transform into vehicle mode has a lot of unrealized potential. Still, this game is completely worthwhile, especially for fans of the franchise.

The problems with previous renditions of Transformers games were probably due to time constraints and goals of quick cash ins. Fortunately, War for Cybertron transcends these limitations as it's neither based off a movie nor a rushed product hoping to ride the wave of passing trends. This particular game outshines the rest. First off, the story is original and different from what we've become accustomed to. Humans are out of the equation and this game focuses on the start of the schism that separated the infamous race of robots. Even better than the campaign though is the multiplayer. The online plays a lot like Call of Duty in that your weapons are customizable and you are rewarded with killstreak bonuses. The cherry on top though, is that you can transform from robot to vehicle any time you want. Needless to say, it's a blast and a must play for fans of third person shooters and the series alike.\n\nGrade: B+

Transformers: War for Cybertron has brought back so many memories from my childhood that I can't even begin to explain all of them. Starting from the classic cartoons to the most memorable Beast Wars in the 1990s...

If I realized one thing about Transformers, it's the various stories that branch from the original one. It's like the story had so many different parts to it that you could actually see how big that Transformers storyline, no.. universe spanned. For those followers and fans of Transformers, War for Cybertron would be centered around the Generation 1 continuity which is safe to say, .. the original storyline.

Dealing with the Great Cybertronian War (Third Cybertronian War), the Autobots and Decepticons have been waging war over countless millenia spanned across the universe. The conflict of ideals and justice that seem to be so deeply rooted that brothers are forced to fight each other and choose sides. ... Well, at least that's my take on the war too.

But I digress. There are two story arcs to play through in T:WFC, the Decepticon Saga and the Autobot Saga in Single Player Campaign and the Multiplayer mode. The campaign mode is played from two wholly different perspectives, The Autobots and Decepticons and the personalities experienced in both are so in conflict that you'll immediately see their stances in the war.
T:WFC gives you a choice of playing different characters throughout the story arcs so you can take the fight to the skies even. Both ground and air combat is enjoyable enough. You can even play co-op campaign mode upto a max of 3 players so bring friends if you want.

What took it for me was playing co-op through the story campaign with my brother. Also Optimus Prime's original voice actor, Peter Cullen. No comparison.

If you're new to Transformers, give it a play through and you won't regret it.. it's the best Transformers game in years. And for the fans, you already know that.

Either way, .. Transformers: WFC will be leading you to believe that there's more than meets the eye.

My favorite piece of Transformers media. This game sort of leads up to the Transformers Prime series, but not perfectly.

The gameplay is simple, just a third person shooter with a decent variety of weapons and a bunch of Transformers to play as. You can transform to go quicker and use that weapon, and in robot mode you have 2 different perks you can use to damage enemies or buff your teammates. The voice acting is incredible, with Peter Cullen as Optimus, Johnny Yong Bosch as Bumblebee, Fred Tatascoire as Megatron, and Sam Reigel as Starscream, just to name a few.

The multiplayer is pretty simple, just a bunch of basic modes like deathmatch or capture the flag. The best part of it is the character customization, where you can use the chassis or any playable character, along with Arcee if you've finished the Autobot campaign, and Slipstream if you finished the Decepticon one. You can color them any way you want and choose from a set of weapons and perks for each class, which is decided by vehicle type. The only problem is that I've found the multiplayer to be mostly abandoned today, though it is fun if you can get some opponents.

The story follows the titular War for Cybertron, before the Transformers came to Earth. The Decepticon campaign comes before the Autobot one, so to get the full story, just play in level order, though you can play Autobot first. Overall, an amazing game. 9.5 out of 10, not totally perfect, but pretty great.

Transformers War for Cybertron takes place on the planet cybertron and tells the story of the two sides, autobots and decepticons as they fight for control of the planet. Right off the bat you can choose  between the autobot campaign or decepticon campaign. If you want to go in order of events then play the decepticon campaign first with the autobot campaign taking place after the events of the decepticons. The stories of both campaigns are very well done with you tearing apart the autobots as the decepticons then trying to fix things as the autobots. Each campaign offers a variety of characters to play as all being veterans of the transformers series. The missions in the campaign are each about an hour long or more offering plenty of playtime throughout the entire game. there are two types of levels, the normal ground missions where you play as the vehicle transformers like optimus or megatron. Then there are the air levels where you can play as characters like starscream and jetfire. Both are very fun and challenging in their own right. One of my favorite things to do in this game is transform which is something you can do just about any time you want and really gives it a transformers vibe to it. Another aspect I really enjoyed was the designs of the characters they still held their trademark appearances, but at the same time had a cybertronian style as well. One thing that is slightly annoying is the framerates are a little slow around a 30 benchmark. This could be due to not changing settings on my end, or it could be that it was locked at 30 either way it isnt too noticeable. There is a multiplayer and coop section, coop being for the campaign or escalation gamemode however I did not try either as there are not many people who still play the multiplayer of this game. Overall this game is a great transformers game that can appeal to hardcore fans but also be something for new people to enjoy that is well worth the 20$.
